title: Kubernetes Secrets Manager Privilege Escalation via RBAC Misconfiguration

timeline.event: Privilege escalation path discovered in Kubernetes secrets RBAC
Active exploitation observed in the wild

simple_summary.what_happened: A privilege escalation vulnerability was found in how Kubernetes handles RBAC permissions for secrets. Users with limited secret access can escalate to read all secrets in a namespace or cluster by exploiting overly permissive default service account configurations.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: All Kubernetes clusters including managed services (EKS, AKS, GKE) that haven't implemented strict RBAC policies. Clusters using default service accounts or those with 'get secrets' permissions in any namespace are vulnerable.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Attacker gains access to a pod with limited permissions. Step 2: They identify RBAC misconfigurations allowing secret enumeration. Step 3: They escalate to read secrets from other namespaces. Step 4: Database passwords, API keys, and certificates are extracted. Step 5: Attacker uses stolen credentials to access external systems.
what_you_should_do: Audit all RBAC roles and role bindings for secret access
Disable automounting of service account tokens where not needed
Implement namespace isolation with Network Policies
Use external secrets managers (AWS Secrets Manager, HashiCorp Vault)
Apply the principle of least privilege to all service accounts
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: Kubernetes secrets contain the most sensitive data in your cluster - database credentials, API keys, TLS certificates, and service account tokens. If attackers can read secrets, they can access every system those secrets protect. This is often the path from initial access to full infrastructure compromise.

tactics.description: Attackers exploit default service accounts with excessive permissions
Attackers query Kubernetes API to extract secrets
Attackers use stolen credentials to access external services

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor Kubernetes audit logs for secret access patterns, RBAC changes, and service account usage. Watch for secrets being read by unexpected principals.

log_sources.description: API server audit logs showing all resource access

what_to_look_for.description: Multiple secrets accessed in rapid succession
Service accounts accessing secrets in other namespaces
New role bindings granting secret access

immediate_actions.description: Find all roles and bindings that grant secret access
immediate_actions.command: kubectl get clusterrolebindings,rolebindings -A -o json | jq '.items[] | select(.roleRef.name | test("secret"))'

immediate_actions.description: Prevent automatic token mounting in pods that don't need it
Update to the latest patched Kubernetes version
Ensure comprehensive audit logging is enabled
List all pods using non-default service accounts
